key_points: Reports emerge of the Taliban beating Afghans trying to flee the country, undermining promises of "safe passage" to Kabul airport.
The Taliban controls all land borders of Afghanistan, making the Kabul airport, secured by the US military, the only exit point.
Violence reported at Taliban checkpoints on Airport Road, including instances of women and children being beaten.
US national security adviser Jake Sullivan and White House press secretary Jen Psaki express concern over the situation and warn of holding the Taliban accountable.
13 flights airlifted 1,100 US citizens, permanent residents, and their families from Kabul on Tuesday, with more expected.
Amrullah Saleh, Afghanistan's first vice-president, declares himself the "legitimate caretaker president" and refuses to bow to the Taliban.
Saleh calls for resistance against the Taliban, echoing the spirit of the Northern Alliance.
Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau states he has no plans to recognize the Taliban as Afghanistan's government.
US Air Force investigates deaths related to civilians trying to cling to departing aircraft at Kabul's airport.
Taliban has acquired a significant amount of US military equipment, including advanced weaponry and Black Hawk helicopters.
